Chapter 12: Amusement and Observation
At that time, the prince grew up in the royal palace. As a child, he played and did not learn. When he was eight years old, he left the palace to go to school.

He studied various texts and all kinds of treatises, as well as military arts, from the two great masters ViÅ›vÄmitra and Indra. After four years, when he was twelve years old, he had mastered all kinds of skills.
Having mastered them, he followed worldly customs, pleasing his eyes and satisfying his mind, indulging in wantonness and chasing after sounds and colors.
Once, in the Qiuyuan Garden, he went out to play archery. The other five hundred ÅšÄkya youths were also playing in their own gardens.
At that time, a flock of geese was flying in the sky. Devadatta, the young man, drew his bow and shot one of the geese.
The goose, struck by the arrow, fell into the garden of SiddhÄrtha.

When the prince saw the goose wounded by an arrow falling to the ground, he gently picked it up with both hands. Having picked it up, he sat cross-legged and placed the goose on his lap. With his hand of blessings and virtues, which was smooth, slippery, soft, moist, and had the pattern of a thousand-spoked wheel, he held the goose with his left hand and pulled out the arrow with his right hand. He then sealed the wound with ghee and honey.
At that time, Devadatta, the young man, sent a messenger to the prince, saying:
I shot a goose and it fell into your garden. You should quickly return it to me and not keep it.
At that time, the prince replied to the messenger, saying:
If the goose dies, I will return it to you;
If he does not die, he will never be obtained.'
At that time, Devadatta again sent a messenger to say:
'Whether he dies or lives, you must definitely return him to me. I skillfully shot him first and he happened to fall into your hands. How can you suddenly keep him?'
The prince replied:
'I have already accepted this goose first.
The reason is that since I gave rise to the bodhi mind, I have accepted all sentient beings, let alone this goose not belonging to me.'
For this reason, they immediately competed, gathering the elders and wise people of the Shakyas to decide this matter.
At that time, a god from the Pure Abodes transformed his body into an old elder, entered the assembly of the Shakyas, and said these words:
'Who raised and nurtured him?
That one has accepted him.
The one who shot him is the one who let him go.'
At that time, the elders of the ÅšÄkyas all agreed and shouted loudly,
It is just as you have said.
This is the first cause of enmity between Devadatta and the prince.
Once again, King Åšuddhodana, together with many young ÅšÄkyas and the prince, went out to the fields to watch the planting.

At that time, the workers in the fields were toiling with bare chests, plowing the land. The oxen were tethered, and when they walked slowly, they were sometimes dragged by the plow. The sun was long and the sky was hot, and the oxen panted and sweated from exhaustion and thirst. Both the people and the oxen were all exhausted and hungry.
Moreover, their bodies were emaciated and their bones were connected, and from under the plowed soil, insects emerged.
After the people and the plow had passed, birds flew down to compete for and eat these insects.
The prince saw the exhausted oxen, whipped and beaten, their necks chafed by the plow, their throats constricted by the reins, blood flowing from their lower parts, their skin and flesh wounded.
He also saw the plowmen, their backs scorched by the sun, naked and exposed, their bodies covered in dust, with crows flying down to pick at the insects on their bodies.
When the prince saw this, he was greatly saddened.
It was like when someone sees their close relatives being bound and taken away, they are filled with great sorrow. The prince's compassion for those beings was also like this.

Having seen this, he gave rise to great compassion. He then descended from the king of horses Kanthaka, and after descending, he paced slowly, contemplating the beings who had such things happening to them, and then he exclaimed:
Alas, alas!

The beings in the world are experiencing extreme suffering, namely birth, old age, sickness, and death, and they are also undergoing various kinds of distress, revolving within it and unable to escape.
How can I not seek to abandon these sufferings?
How can I not seek to be disgusted with and pacify the wisdom of suffering?
How can I not think of escaping the causes of the suffering of birth, old age, sickness, and death?
Where can I now find a secluded place to contemplate such matters of suffering and distress?'
At that time, King Åšuddhodana, having observed the farming, returned with the young men to a garden.
At that time, the prince, looking around leisurely, was walking here and there, wishing to seek tranquility.
He suddenly saw a place with an Indian fig tree, with smooth trunk and branches, upright and lovely, lush and dense, pleasing to the eye.
Having seen it, he immediately said to the attendants,
'You people,
all of you stay away from me. I wish to go alone.'
At that time, the prince dismissed the attendants, letting them all disperse, and gradually reached the foot of the tree.

Having arrived under the tree, he sat cross-legged on the grass, contemplating the various sufferings of sentient beings due to birth, old age, sickness, and death, giving rise to compassion, and immediately attained mental concentration.
At that time, he immediately became free from desires and abandoned all unwholesome dharmas.
Contemplating the objects, discerning the objects, the defilements of the desire realm were exhausted, and he attained the first dhyÄna.
'My body also has such dharmas, and I have not escaped from these dharmas, I have not crossed over this wheel.'

When he was contemplating like this, there were five divine sages who flew through the sky, moving freely, with great authority and power, fully possessing the skill and penetration of the Vedas, well-versed in various arts. From the south heading north, they wanted to fly over the garden forest and the Jambu tree, but they were unable to go.
They said to each other:

Those sages then looked at the tree and saw the prince sitting in meditation under the shade of the tree, his majestic radiance so brilliant that it was difficult to look at.
Having seen this, they thought:
'Who is sitting there?

Could it be that this is the great Brahma King, the lord of the world, or the desire realm king Isana, or the heavenly king Shakra, or the great treasury lord Vaisravana, or the moon god, or the sun god, or perhaps a wheel-turning sage king, or is it someone who has attained Buddhahood in this world?'
'However, this person's majestic virtue is very great.'
At that time, the forest guardian deity said to the sages:
The sages, this is not the great Brahma, the lord of the world, not the desire realm king Isana, not the heavenly king Shakra or the treasury lord Vaisravana, nor is it the moon or sun god;
This prince is named Siddhartha, the youth of the Shakya clan, the son of King Shuddhodana.

At that time, a sage spoke a verse, saying:

Having attained such subtle Dharma, it extinguishes the burning fire of afflictions without remainder.
Again, a sage spoke a verse, saying:
The sage said: 'In the world, ignorance is very dark, but this can give rise to the light of wisdom.
Having attained such a subtle Dharma, it illuminates the blind darkness of the entire world.'
Another sage spoke a verse, saying:

Having attained such a subtle Dharma, it can deliver all beings from the three realms of existence.'
Another sage spoke a verse, saying:
All worldly beings are bound by afflictions, but this skillful means can liberate them.
Having attained such a subtle Dharma, it can free one from all bonds and fetters.'
Another sage spoke a verse, saying:
In the world, all beings are sick with birth and death, but this great physician can cure them.

At that time, the sages each spoke verses in praise of the prince, joined their palms in respect, circumambulated him three times to the right, and flew up into the sky, following one another as they left.
At that time, King Åšuddhodana, in an instant, did not see the prince, and his heart immediately gave rise to unhappiness and discontent, and asked someone, saying:
'Where is my prince now? (The above two sentences are repeated in the Sanskrit text.)
Suddenly he is nowhere to be seen.'
At that time, the ministers ran back and forth in all directions, searching for the prince, but did not know where he was.

At that time, a great minister saw the prince under the shade of a jambu tree, sitting in meditation in thought, and also saw that the shadows of all the trees had shifted, only the jambu shade alone covered the prince.
At that time, the great minister, seeing this rare and inconceivable event with the prince, was overjoyed, filled with rapture, and could not contain himself.
He quickly ran to the king's place, knelt for a long time, and according to what he saw, he immediately spoke a verse, saying:
The great king's prince is now sitting upright under the shade of a jambu tree,
With his legs crossed, contemplating and entering samadhi, his radiance illuminating like the sun and a mountain.
This is truly a great man, the tree's shadow standing still without moving,
I only wish the great king would observe for himself how the prince sits with his appearance.
It is like the great Brahma kings of the heavens, and also like the Shakra of the Heaven of the Thirty-three,
With majestic and lofty radiance and splendor, illuminating the forests of trees everywhere.

When King Åšuddhodana heard this, he immediately went to the rose apple tree. When the king saw this, he gave rise to a mind of great wonder and marvel, trembling all over, his body hair standing on end. He then bowed his head to the prince's feet, overjoyed and elated, and said these words:

My prince has great majestic virtue.
He spoke a verse in praise, saying:

Then King Åšuddhodana, having praised with a verse, again bowed his head to the feet of the prince, and spoke a verse again, saying:

At that time, there were small children carrying baskets and nets who followed the great king, chirping and playing.
A great minister scolded those small children, saying such words:

Fortunately, do not shout and make noise.
At that time, the small children replied to that minister, saying:

At that time, the great minister then answered with a verse to all those small children, saying:

Contemplating, sitting upright under the tree, unmoving and unshakable like Mount Sumeru,
